citations.narrative:
The primary enclosure for the domestic rabbits had a water receptacle that contained a small amount of water and had an
excessive amount of shavings and debris. This poses a risk of contamination to the enclosed rabbits. Water receptacles
for rabbits must be cleaned and sanitized when dirty to keep them free from contamination.
Correct from 8-29-2024 onward.

The enclosure housing an alpaca, deer, cavy, and goat contained no grain or hay. When hay was offered, the alpaca and
the deer immediately started eating and continued eating steadily for more than ten minutes. This is an indication these
animals are not being fed as often as necessary to satisfy their natural drive to forage throughout the day which is
important for proper rumen function. Animals must be fed sufficient amounts and at an appropriate frequency to maintain
good health.
Correct from 8-29-2024 onward.

The cages housing the African gray parrot, cockatoo, and macaws had dirty water receptacles that contained excessive
amounts of feed and debris. This poses a risk of contamination to the enclosed birds. Water receptacles for birds must be
cleaned and sanitized as often as necessary to keep them free from contamination.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The enclosure housing the cockatoo had a thick layer of spilled feed, waste, bedding material, and debris covering the
tray underneath the wire cage floor. A large number of flies were buzzing around inside this lower portion of the cage.
Accumulated waste is a potential source of contamination to the enclosed animal and increases the risk of disease,
insects, and pests. Excreta and food waste must be removed from within and under the primary enclosure as often as
necessary to prevent excessive accumulation.
Correct by 8-29-2024 onward.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
There appears to be a lack of adequate pest control procedures at the facility. Large numbers of flies were observed
around the cockatoo enclosure. In the food storage area, there was a trash can full of waste with no lid. There were
numerous flies on and around this trash can. There were multiple trash cans located throughout the facility without lids.
Open trash cans are an attractant to flies and pests, and improper storage of waste can result in pest infestation and
disease hazards. The licensee must create and maintain an effective program for the control of pests so as to promote
the health and well being of the animals.
To be corrected by 09-07-2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
MICHAEL TYGART, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.55 
   
Watering. 
The primary enclosure for the domestic rabbits had a water receptacle that contained a small amount of water and had an 
excessive amount of shavings and debris. This poses a risk of contamination to the enclosed rabbits. Water receptacles 
for rabbits must be cleaned and sanitized when dirty to keep them free from contamination. 
 
Correct from 8-29-2024 onward. 
3.129(a) 
   
Feeding. 
The enclosure housing an alpaca, deer, cavy, and goat contained no grain or hay. When hay was offered, the alpaca and 
the deer immediately started eating and continued eating steadily for more than ten minutes. This is an indication these 
animals are not being fed as often as necessary to satisfy their natural drive to forage throughout the day which is 
important for proper rumen function. Animals must be fed sufficient amounts and at an appropriate frequency to maintain 
good health. 
 
Correct from 8-29-2024 onward. 
3.156  Repeat
   
Watering 
The cages housing the African gray parrot, cockatoo, and macaws had dirty water receptacles that contained excessive 
amounts of feed and debris. This poses a risk of contamination to the enclosed birds. Water receptacles for birds must be 
cleaned and sanitized as often as necessary to keep them free from contamination. 
3.158(a)(1) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The enclosure housing the cockatoo had a thick layer of spilled feed, waste, bedding material, and debris covering the 
tray underneath the wire cage floor. A large number of flies were buzzing around inside this lower portion of the cage. 
Accumulated waste is a potential source of contamination to the enclosed animal and increases the risk of disease,

insects, and pests. Excreta and food waste must be removed from within and under the primary enclosure as often as 
necessary to prevent excessive accumulation. 
 
Correct by 8-29-2024 onward. 
3.158(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
There appears to be a lack of adequate pest control procedures at the facility. Large numbers of flies were observed 
around the cockatoo enclosure. In the food storage area, there was a trash can full of waste with no lid. There were 
numerous flies on and around this trash can. There were multiple trash cans located throughout the facility without lids. 
Open trash cans are an attractant to flies and pests, and improper storage of waste can result in pest infestation and 
disease hazards. The licensee must create and maintain an effective program for the control of pests so as to promote 
the health and well being of the animals. 
 
To be corrected by 09-07-2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
MICHAEL TYGART, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
